remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to suppress a script error and display your own custom dialog box. This code example requires that your application host a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.WebBrowser> control named `webBrowser1`.
[!code-csharp[System.Windows.Forms.HtmlWindow#16](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.HtmlWindow/CS/Form1.cs#16)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.HtmlWindow#16](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.HtmlWindow/VB/Form1.vb#16)]

Docs.summary: Gets the descriptive string corresponding to the error.
Docs.value: The descriptive string corresponding to the error.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HtmlWindow.Error?displayProperty=nameWithType> event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> with <xref:System.Console.WriteLine%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> or appending the message to a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox>.
To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HtmlWindow> named `HtmlWindow1`. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HtmlWindow.Error?displayProperty=nameWithType> event.
[!code-csharp[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#451](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples/CS/EventExamples.cs#451)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#451](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples/VB/EventExamples.vb#451)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets whether this error has been handled by the application hosting the document.
Docs.value: if the event has been handled; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Set this property to `true` if you wish to display your own custom error message to the user, or suppress the error entirely.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to suppress a script error and display your own custom dialog box. This code example requires that your application host a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.WebBrowser> control named `webBrowser1`.
[!code-csharp[System.Windows.Forms.HtmlWindow#16](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.HtmlWindow/CS/Form1.cs#16)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.HtmlWindow#16](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.HtmlWindow/VB/Form1.vb#16)]

public: property int LineNumber { int get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the line of HTML script code on which the error occurred.
Docs.value: An designating the script line number.

## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HtmlWindow.Error?displayProperty=nameWithType> event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> with <xref:System.Console.WriteLine%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> or appending the message to a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox>.

Docs.summary: Gets the location of the document that generated the error.
Docs.value: A that represents the location of the document that generated the error.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If you are hosting an HTML document that contains frames, it might not be evident which frame is responsible for generating the error. Use this property to provide debugging information so that a developer can better narrow down the problem.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HtmlWindow.Error?displayProperty=nameWithType> event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> with <xref:System.Console.WriteLine%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> or appending the message to a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox>.
To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HtmlWindow> named `HtmlWindow1`. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HtmlWindow.Error?displayProperty=nameWithType> event.
